Title: The Goldfinch
Review: I tried to enjoy this book, but I couldn't. The unnecessary, lengthy descriptive narrations made the reading experience quite boring. I found myself skipping through sections in the hopes that, at some point, I would start liking this book and understand why readers loved it, but that never happened. Overall, the plot was good, but the book could have been a few hundred pages shorter.

Title: None of This Is True
Contributors: Louise Brealey (Narrator), Emilia Fox (Narrator), Elliot Fitzpatrick (Narrator), Ayesha Antoine (Narrator), Thomas Judd (Narrator), Alix Dunmore (Narrator), Kate MacDonald (Narrator), Dominic Thorburn (Narrator), Jenny Walser (Narrator), Nicola Walker (Narrator), Kristin Atherton (Narrator)

Title: A Court of Mist and Fury
Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
Death's End
Review:
I was initially skeptical about the Remembrance of Earth’s Past series, particularly the first book, which I found just okay. 
The second book started slow for me, but I grew more invested as the story progressed, especially in the latter half. 
However, it was Death’s End that truly captivated me. The third book is a remarkable conclusion to the series, even though I felt the last few chapters were a bit rushed. While I initially underestimated the series due to the seemingly boring philosophical sections, I’ve come to appreciate that they were essential to the depth and complexity of the story. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed the series and would recommend it to anyone interested in hard science fiction.

Title: Flowers for Algernon
Review: I experienced a range of emotions while reading this book. It was a devastating, heartbreaking, and beautiful read.

Review: 4.5! I loved this book. Even though some parts felt dragged, it is still beautifully written.

Review: 4.0-4.5! I thoroughly enjoyed listening to this audiobook. Some parts felt ridiculous and unrealistic, but well, that was expected since it is a teenager solving a murder case. Overall, the story is quite entertaining.

Title: The Paris Apartment
Contributors: Clare Corbett (Narrator), Julia Winwood (Narrator), Daphne Kouma (Narrator), Charlie Anson (Narrator), Sofia Zervudachi (Narrator), Sope Dirisu (Narrator)
Review: The author drags out the background stories of all the characters, and the 'mystery-thriller' part was rushed in the last few chapters.

Title: The Family Upstairs
Contributors: Dominic Thorburn (Narrator), Bea Holland (Narrator), Tamaryn Payne (Narrator)

Title: The Dark Forest
Review:
I almost DNF'd this book at 50%. After watching the disastrous last few episodes of the Netflix series I went back to reading this book so I would know how the story truly unfolds—and I’m glad I did. 

This book is way better than the first book. Some sections bored me and I found myself skimming through them and some sections I had "WTF, WOW!" moments. I ended up liking the latter half of the book. The way the author has constructed this narrative is mind-boggling. Now that I've finished this one, I’m committed to completing the entire series.

Title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
Review: When I first read the summary of this book, I couldn't wait to dive into its pages. I loved reading this book. The novel explores themes of identity, memory, and the human desire to leave a mark on the world. The concept was great, but it did seem to be lacking in parts. The last few chapters were undoubtedly the best. It wasn't as amazing as I initially thought it would be, but it is worthy of a recommendation - a thought-provoking and enjoyable read.

Title: Babel
Review: I loved this book; it is well-researched and well-written. It was a slow start; however, as the plot evolved, the story became gripping and gut-wrenching. The author's discussions on linguistics and etymology are easily my favourite part of the book.
